security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and helper script skill focused on Git operations. The shell script (git_helper.sh) provides interactive utilities for branch cleanup, conflict resolution, and rebase assistance. All capabilities are standard Git operations with no network calls to external endpoints, no credential access, and no persistence mechanisms. User confirmations are required before destructive operations.

content.user_title: Master advanced Git operations and workflows
content.value_statement: Complex Git operations like interactive rebasing, conflict resolution, and history rewriting can be error-prone without guidance. This skill provides step-by-step workflows, examples, and helper scripts to safely navigate advanced version control scenarios.
actual_capabilities: Interactive rebasing with squash, reorder, edit, and split operations
Strategic merge conflict resolution using ours, theirs, and manual approaches
Git bisect for binary search bug hunting across commit history
Commit recovery using reflog and fsck for lost work restoration
Branch strategy implementation for Git Flow, trunk-based, and GitHub Flow workflows
Helper script for branch cleanup, stash management, and history visualization
limitations: Does not execute Git operations automatically - provides guidance and examples only
Does not access or modify repositories outside the current working directory
Does not integrate with remote services or CI/CD pipelines directly
User must confirm all destructive operations like branch deletion and force push

use_cases.title: Clean up commit history
use_cases.description: Squash WIP commits, reorder changes, and create readable commit history before code review

use_cases.title: Implement branch strategies
use_cases.description: Set up Git Flow, trunk-based development, or custom branching workflows for team coordination

use_cases.title: Recover lost commits
use_cases.description: Use reflog and recovery techniques to restore accidentally deleted branches and commits

prompt_templates.title: Rebase assistance
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me use interactive rebase to squash the last 5 commits into one clean commit with a descriptive message

prompt_templates.title: Conflict resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through resolving merge conflicts between my feature branch and main, including when to use ours versus theirs

prompt_templates.title: Bug hunting
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to use git bisect to find which commit introduced a bug that exists now but was not present in version 1.0.0

prompt_templates.title: Recovery
prompt_templates.prompt: I accidentally reset my branch and lost important commits. Help me recover them using reflog

output_examples.input: Help me squash my last 4 commits into one
output: Step 1: Create a backup branch first to ensure you can recover if needed
Step 2: Start interactive rebase for the last 4 commits
Step 3: In the editor, change 'pick' to 'squash' for commits 2, 3, and 4
Step 4: Save and edit the combined commit message
Step 5: Verify the result with git log --oneline

best_practices: Always create a backup branch before rebasing or rewriting history
Never rebase commits that have been pushed to shared branches
Use git reflog to recover from mistakes - it preserves 30-90 days of HEAD history
anti_patterns: Rebasing public branches that others depend on
Skipping commit message review during interactive rebase
Ignoring conflict markers without understanding both sides

faq.question: Does this skill work with all Git hosting platforms?
faq.answer: Yes, the commands work with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and self-hosted Git servers.

faq.question: What are the limits of git bisect?
faq.answer: Requires a test that can return pass/fail. Best for clear bug scenarios with known good and bad commits.

faq.question: Can I use this with GitHub CLI or GitLab CLI?
faq.answer: Yes, the Git commands are compatible with any Git CLI regardless of hosting platform.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using the helper script?
faq.answer: The script requires user confirmation before destructive actions and only operates in the current repository.

faq.question: Why did my rebase fail?
faq.answer: Most failures are from conflicts. Abort with git rebase --abort, resolve conflicts, then continue or start over.

faq.question: How is this different from standard Git documentation?
faq.answer: This skill provides interactive guidance, workflow examples, and a helper script that streamlines complex operations.
